{{Infobox writer | name = Anne Lamott | image = Anne-Lamott-2013-San-Francisco.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|4|10}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco, California]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, non-fiction writer, essayist, memoirist | nationality = American | period= | genre= [[Drama]], [[humor]], [[literary fiction]] | subject= | movement= | notableworks = | spouse= | children = 1 son | relatives= | influences= | first = | last = | authorlink = | title = | publisher = | year = | isbn = }} '''Anne Lamott''' (born April 10, 1954) is an American novelist and non-fiction writer. She is also a [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] political activist, public speaker, and writing teacher. Based in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], her nonfiction works are largely autobiographical. Marked by their self-deprecating humor and openness, Lamott's writings cover such subjects as [[alcoholism]], [[Single parent|single-motherhood]], [[Clinical depression|depression]], and [[Christianity]].{{cite_journal |url=http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2006/05/22/lamott_fight_son/ |last=Lamott |first=Anne |journal=Salon |title=My son, the stranger |accessdate=2008-03-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080513034405/http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2006/05/22/lamott_fight_son/| archivedate=May 13, 2008| deadurl= no}} ==Life and career== Lamott was born in [[San Francisco]], and is a graduate of [[Drew School]]. She was a student at [[Goucher College]] for two years where she wrote for the newspaper.{{cite web|last1=Flanagan|first1=Mark|title=Anne Lamott|url=http://contemporarylit.about.com/od/authorprofiles/p/Anne-Lamott-biography.htm|website=About Entertainment|accessdate=4 November 2014}} Her father, Kenneth Lamott, was also a writer. Her first published novel ''Hard Laughter'' was written for him after his diagnosis of brain cancer. She has one son, Sam, who was born in August 1989 and a grandson, Jax, born in July 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/06/living/anne-lamott-boomer/index.html|last=Hetter|first=Katia|date=6 April 2012|title=Anne Lamott's directions for grandparents: 'Some Assembly Required'|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=6 April 2012}} In 1994 Lamott was living in [[San Rafael, California]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/01/garden/at-home-with-anne-lamott-laughter-death-lollipops.html?pagewanted=all AT HOME WITH - Anne Lamott - Laughter, Death, Lollipops - NYTimes.com] Retrieved 2016-12-17. Lamott's life was documented in [[Freida Lee Mock]]'s 1999 documentary ''Bird by Bird with Annie: A Film Portrait of Writer Anne Lamott''.{{cite video |people = Freida Lee Mock (Director) |date = 1999-08-01 |title = Bird by Bird with Annie |url = http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0202259/ |medium = Documentary |publisher = Vanguard International Cinema}} Because of the documentary and her following on Facebook and other online networks, she is often called the "People's Author".{{cite news|url=http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/201004/20100414.html|last=Smiley|first=Tavis|date=14 April 2010|title=Interview with Anne Lamott|publisher=PBS|accessdate=14 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100416170741/http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/201004/20100414.html| archivedate= 16 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} Lamott has described why she writes:
I try to write the books I would love to come upon, that are honest, concerned with real lives, human hearts, spiritual transformation, families, secrets, wonder, craziness—and that can make me laugh. When I am reading a book like this, I feel rich and profoundly relieved to be in the presence of someone who will share the truth with me, and throw the lights on a little, and I try to write these kinds of books. Books, for me, are medicine.{{cite_web |url=http://religion.beloblog.com/archives/2008/02/quote_of_the_day_60.html |work=Religion Blog |publisher=Dallas Morning News |date=2008-02-10 |title=Quote of the Day}}
Lamott is cited as a writer who captures well the style of narrative nonfiction called [[Literary particularism|particularism]], coined by Howard Freeman.Rice, Priscilla. [http://www.prweb.com/releases/San_Francisco/recording-studio/prweb9140334.htm New York Times Bestseller Anne Lamott and Son Sam Record New Novel at Live Oak Studio in Berkeley]. PR News.
